Syracuse Overseas Program Continues
With PM-Flight 103-Syracuse, b0140
DOC.TEXT: The bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 has not reduced the popularity of Syracuse University's overseas study program, its director says. No one backed out of the International Studies Abroad program last spring, just after 35 returning students were killed in the bombing, Nirelle Galson said. A handful of students did switch flights from an American airline to a foreign one, she said. In the just ended semester, about 820 students went abroad to study, about a 10 percent increase, she said. ``We had a number of parents and students call asking about safety prior to departure, but it seemed they were simply seeking reassuarances,'' said Galson. ``I thought we'd have some downturn in the spring, but it hasn't happened. But I can't say we wouldn't have had a 20 percent increase (in participation) if it didn't happen.''
